title: How to Clean Jewelry with Baking Soda

steps.headline: Pour 1 cup (237 mL) of hot water into a bowl.
steps.description: Pick a bowl in an appropriate size for the jewelry you are cleaning. You only need about 1 cup (237 mL) of hot water to clean most items. Use hot water from your faucet, or microwave the water in the bowl for 30 seconds or so. Use a bit more water if cleaning a large necklace, for instance.

steps.headline: Mix in 1-2 tsp (5-10 g) of baking soda.
steps.description: Use a measuring device to scoop up 1-2 tsp (5-10 g) of baking soda and pour it into the bowl. Then, stir the ingredients together with a spoon so the baking soda dissolves. If you are having trouble mixing the baking soda into the water, heat it up in the microwave for 30 seconds or so.

steps.headline: Soak your jewelry in the solution for 5-10 minutes.
steps.description: Place the jewelry into the bowl of baking soda solution. Ensure the jewelry is completely covered in the water. Then, set a timer for 5-10 minutes so the baking soda can work its magic. You can clean multiple pieces of jewelry at the same time. The baking soda solution strips off surface dirt and debris, giving jewelry of all types a superficial clean.

steps.headline: Rinse the item in cool water to remove the baking soda and residue.
steps.description: After your jewelry soaks for a while, it should be mostly clean. Take it out of the bowl, pour your solution down the drain, and wash the jewelry in cool water. If you have rings or small earrings, fill your bowl with cool water and place the jewelry inside. This way, they do not slip out of your hands. Do this for valuable jewelry too if you’d like.

steps.headline: Pat the jewelry dry with a clean towel.
steps.description: After you rinse your jewelry, locate a clean rag or paper towel to get rid of the excess water. Be sure to dry your jewelry right away to keep it in great condition. Wear your jewelry right away or place it inside your jewelry box.

steps.headline: Mix together 3 parts of baking soda with 1 part of water.
steps.description: Grab a small dish and pour in 3 parts of baking soda. Then, add 1 part of water to make your solution paste-like. Use more or less baking soda based on how many items you are cleaning. For instance, mix 3 tbsp (45 g) of baking soda with 1 tbsp (15 g) of water to clean a few pieces of jewelry. This is a great way to scrub stubborn residue off of very dirty or tarnished jewelry.

steps.headline: Stir up your ingredients until you get a paste-like consistency.
steps.description: Use the back of a toothbrush to mix the baking soda and water. Continue stirring until you get a solid paste. If it’s difficult to mix the ingredients, add a few more drops of water. If it’s easier for you, use a spoon to mix the ingredients instead.

steps.headline: Dip a clean toothbrush into the paste to get some on the bristles.
steps.description: Scoop up a generous amount of the paste so you can completely cover the item. Aim to get the paste on all of the bristles if you can. If you need more baking soda as you go, simply dip your brush back into the dish. If you don’t have an extra toothbrush handy, use a cotton swab instead. Never use a dirty toothbrush or you could damage your jewelry or spread germs.

steps.headline: Scrub your jewelry gently with the toothbrush.
steps.description: You can hold the item in your hands or place it on a paper towel as you clean it. Then, bring the bristles to the item and move the toothbrush back and forth repeatedly. Scrub 1 jewelry item at a time. For best results, use a soft-bristled brush. These work well to get into small crevices of pendants, bracelets, and rings.

steps.headline: Continue scrubbing the piece for 1-2 minutes for a thorough clean.
steps.description: The amount of time you scrub may vary depending on the size and condition of your piece. In general, you want to scrub until the stubborn residue is gone. To check how clean the jewelry is, simply wipe off some of the baking soda and take a peek.

steps.headline: Remove baking soda and debris with cool water.
steps.description: After you scrub the item clean, you can either dip it in a cup of water or run it under your faucet. Wet your jewelry for 30 seconds or so to get rid of the remaining baking soda.

steps.headline: Place your jewelry on a towel to let it dry.
steps.description: Lay a clean towel next to the sink, and put your jewelry on top after you rinse it clean. Leave the jewelry on the towel for 5-10 minutes to ensure it dries completely.

methods.name: Cleaning Faux Gold and Silver Jewelry

steps.headline: Heat up 1 cup (237 mL) of water in the microwave for 1-2 minutes.
steps.description: Pour roughly 1 cup (237 mL) of water into a microwave-safe bowl. Then, set your timer for 1-2 minutes to warm up the water.

steps.headline: Place aluminum foil inside the bowl to keep track of small items.
steps.description: Cut a piece of aluminum foil to the size and shape of the bowl, then use it as a liner on the inside of the bowl. If you are cleaning large pieces of jewelry, the foil is not needed. It is used to prevent losing small earrings or pendants.

steps.headline: Pour 1 tbsp (15 g) of salt, baking soda, and dish soap each in the bowl.
steps.description: To make your cleaning solution, mix together 1 tbsp (15 g) of table salt, 1 tbsp (15 g) of baking soda, and 1 tbsp (15 mL) of dish soap with a spoon. This combination is great for getting rid of stubborn residue.

steps.headline: Soak your jewelry for 5-10 minutes.
steps.description: You can place several small items in the bowl, just ensure they are completely covered. If cleaning small items, put your jewelry on top of the aluminum foil to help you keep track of it. If you’d like, use a timer to help you keep track of time.

steps.headline: Pour out the solution and rinse off the jewelry.
steps.description: The water gets rid of any lingering salt, baking soda, or soap, as well as the debris that came off. Your jewelry is clean when there is no bubbles or residue in the water.

steps.headline: Dry your jewelry with a cloth after it is clean.
steps.description: Before you put on your jewelry or store it for later use, use a clean towel to pat it dry. Use either a rag or a paper towel to do this.

tyn: Scrubbing with a Baking Soda Paste
Soaking Your Jewelry in Baking Soda and Water
Using Soap, Salt, and Baking Soda
text: Getting a Basic Clean Pour 1 cup (237 mL) of hot water into a bowl. Pick a bowl in an appropriate size for the jewelry you are cleaning. You only need about 1 cup (237 mL) of hot water to clean most items. Use hot water from your faucet, or microwave the water in the bowl for 30 seconds or so. Use a bit more water if cleaning a large necklace, for instance. Mix in 1-2 tsp (5-10 g) of baking soda. Use a measuring device to scoop up 1-2 tsp (5-10 g) of baking soda and pour it into the bowl. Then, stir the ingredients together with a spoon so the baking soda dissolves. If you are having trouble mixing the baking soda into the water, heat it up in the microwave for 30 seconds or so. Soak your jewelry in the solution for 5-10 minutes. Place the jewelry into the bowl of baking soda solution. Ensure the jewelry is completely covered in the water. Then, set a timer for 5-10 minutes so the baking soda can work its magic. You can clean multiple pieces of jewelry at the same time. The baking soda solution strips off surface dirt and debris, giving jewelry of all types a superficial clean. Rinse the item in cool water to remove the baking soda and residue. After your jewelry soaks for a while, it should be mostly clean. Take it out of the bowl, pour your solution down the drain, and wash the jewelry in cool water. If you have rings or small earrings, fill your bowl with cool water and place the jewelry inside. This way, they do not slip out of your hands. Do this for valuable jewelry too if you’d like. Pat the jewelry dry with a clean towel. After you rinse your jewelry, locate a clean rag or paper towel to get rid of the excess water. Be sure to dry your jewelry right away to keep it in great condition. Wear your jewelry right away or place it inside your jewelry box. Removing Stubborn Debris Mix together 3 parts of baking soda with 1 part of water. Grab a small dish and pour in 3 parts of baking soda. Then, add 1 part of water to make your solution paste-like. Use more or less baking soda based on how many items you are cleaning. For instance, mix 3 tbsp (45 g) of baking soda with 1 tbsp (15 g) of water to clean a few pieces of jewelry. This is a great way to scrub stubborn residue off of very dirty or tarnished jewelry. Stir up your ingredients until you get a paste-like consistency. Use the back of a toothbrush to mix the baking soda and water. Continue stirring until you get a solid paste. If it’s difficult to mix the ingredients, add a few more drops of water. If it’s easier for you, use a spoon to mix the ingredients instead. Dip a clean toothbrush into the paste to get some on the bristles. Scoop up a generous amount of the paste so you can completely cover the item. Aim to get the paste on all of the bristles if you can. If you need more baking soda as you go, simply dip your brush back into the dish. If you don’t have an extra toothbrush handy, use a cotton swab instead. Never use a dirty toothbrush or you could damage your jewelry or spread germs. Scrub your jewelry gently with the toothbrush. You can hold the item in your hands or place it on a paper towel as you clean it. Then, bring the bristles to the item and move the toothbrush back and forth repeatedly. Scrub 1 jewelry item at a time. For best results, use a soft-bristled brush. These work well to get into small crevices of pendants, bracelets, and rings. Continue scrubbing the piece for 1-2 minutes for a thorough clean. The amount of time you scrub may vary depending on the size and condition of your piece. In general, you want to scrub until the stubborn residue is gone. To check how clean the jewelry is, simply wipe off some of the baking soda and take a peek. Remove baking soda and debris with cool water. After you scrub the item clean, you can either dip it in a cup of water or run it under your faucet. Wet your jewelry for 30 seconds or so to get rid of the remaining baking soda. Place your jewelry on a towel to let it dry. Lay a clean towel next to the sink, and put your jewelry on top after you rinse it clean. Leave the jewelry on the towel for 5-10 minutes to ensure it dries completely. Cleaning Faux Gold and Silver Jewelry Heat up 1 cup (237 mL) of water in the microwave for 1-2 minutes. Pour roughly 1 cup (237 mL) of water into a microwave-safe bowl. Then, set your timer for 1-2 minutes to warm up the water. Place aluminum foil inside the bowl to keep track of small items. Cut a piece of aluminum foil to the size and shape of the bowl, then use it as a liner on the inside of the bowl. If you are cleaning large pieces of jewelry, the foil is not needed. It is used to prevent losing small earrings or pendants. Pour 1 tbsp (15 g) of salt, baking soda, and dish soap each in the bowl. To make your cleaning solution, mix together 1 tbsp (15 g) of table salt, 1 tbsp (15 g) of baking soda, and 1 tbsp (15 mL) of dish soap with a spoon. This combination is great for getting rid of stubborn residue. Soak your jewelry for 5-10 minutes. You can place several small items in the bowl, just ensure they are completely covered. If cleaning small items, put your jewelry on top of the aluminum foil to help you keep track of it. If you’d like, use a timer to help you keep track of time. Pour out the solution and rinse off the jewelry. The water gets rid of any lingering salt, baking soda, or soap, as well as the debris that came off. Your jewelry is clean when there is no bubbles or residue in the water. Dry your jewelry with a cloth after it is clean. Before you put on your jewelry or store it for later use, use a clean towel to pat it dry. Use either a rag or a paper towel to do this.

Pick a bowl in an appropriate size for the jewelry you are cleaning.
You only need about 1 cup (237 mL) of hot water to clean most items.
Use hot water from your faucet, or microwave the water in the bowl for 30 seconds or so.
Use a bit more water if cleaning a large necklace, for instance.
Mix in 1-2 tsp (5-10 g) of baking soda.
Use a measuring device to scoop up 1-2 tsp (5-10 g) of baking soda and pour it into the bowl.
Then, stir the ingredients together with a spoon so the baking soda dissolves.
If you are having trouble mixing the baking soda into the water, heat it up in the microwave for 30 seconds or so.
Soak your jewelry in the solution for 5-10 minutes.
Place the jewelry into the bowl of baking soda solution.
Ensure the jewelry is completely covered in the water.
Then, set a timer for 5-10 minutes so the baking soda can work its magic.
You can clean multiple pieces of jewelry at the same time.
The baking soda solution strips off surface dirt and debris, giving jewelry of all types a superficial clean.
Rinse the item in cool water to remove the baking soda and residue.
After your jewelry soaks for a while, it should be mostly clean.
Take it out of the bowl, pour your solution down the drain, and wash the jewelry in cool water.
If you have rings or small earrings, fill your bowl with cool water and place the jewelry inside.
This way, they do not slip out of your hands.
Do this for valuable jewelry too if you’d like.
Pat the jewelry dry with a clean towel.
After you rinse your jewelry, locate a clean rag or paper towel to get rid of the excess water.
Be sure to dry your jewelry right away to keep it in great condition.
Wear your jewelry right away or place it inside your jewelry box.
Removing Stubborn Debris Mix together 3 parts of baking soda with 1 part of water.
Grab a small dish and pour in 3 parts of baking soda.
Then, add 1 part of water to make your solution paste-like.
Use more or less baking soda based on how many items you are cleaning.
For instance, mix 3 tbsp (45 g) of baking soda with 1 tbsp (15 g) of water to clean a few pieces of jewelry.
This is a great way to scrub stubborn residue off of very dirty or tarnished jewelry.
Stir up your ingredients until you get a paste-like consistency.
Use the back of a toothbrush to mix the baking soda and water.
Continue stirring until you get a solid paste.
If it’s difficult to mix the ingredients, add a few more drops of water.
If it’s easier for you, use a spoon to mix the ingredients instead.
Dip a clean toothbrush into the paste to get some on the bristles.
Scoop up a generous amount of the paste so you can completely cover the item.
Aim to get the paste on all of the bristles if you can.
If you need more baking soda as you go, simply dip your brush back into the dish.
If you don’t have an extra toothbrush handy, use a cotton swab instead.
Never use a dirty toothbrush or you could damage your jewelry or spread germs.
Scrub your jewelry gently with the toothbrush.
You can hold the item in your hands or place it on a paper towel as you clean it.
Then, bring the bristles to the item and move the toothbrush back and forth repeatedly.
Scrub 1 jewelry item at a time.
For best results, use a soft-bristled brush.
These work well to get into small crevices of pendants, bracelets, and rings.
Continue scrubbing the piece for 1-2 minutes for a thorough clean.
The amount of time you scrub may vary depending on the size and condition of your piece.
In general, you want to scrub until the stubborn residue is gone.
To check how clean the jewelry is, simply wipe off some of the baking soda and take a peek.
Remove baking soda and debris with cool water.
After you scrub the item clean, you can either dip it in a cup of water or run it under your faucet.
Wet your jewelry for 30 seconds or so to get rid of the remaining baking soda.
Place your jewelry on a towel to let it dry.
Lay a clean towel next to the sink, and put your jewelry on top after you rinse it clean.
Leave the jewelry on the towel for 5-10 minutes to ensure it dries completely.
Cleaning Faux Gold and Silver Jewelry Heat up 1 cup (237 mL) of water in the microwave for 1-2 minutes.
Pour roughly 1 cup (237 mL) of water into a microwave-safe bowl.
Then, set your timer for 1-2 minutes to warm up the water.
Place aluminum foil inside the bowl to keep track of small items.
Cut a piece of aluminum foil to the size and shape of the bowl, then use it as a liner on the inside of the bowl.
If you are cleaning large pieces of jewelry, the foil is not needed.
It is used to prevent losing small earrings or pendants.
Pour 1 tbsp (15 g) of salt, baking soda, and dish soap each in the bowl.
To make your cleaning solution, mix together 1 tbsp (15 g) of table salt, 1 tbsp (15 g) of baking soda, and 1 tbsp (15 mL) of dish soap with a spoon.
This combination is great for getting rid of stubborn residue.
Soak your jewelry for 5-10 minutes.
You can place several small items in the bowl, just ensure they are completely covered.
If cleaning small items, put your jewelry on top of the aluminum foil to help you keep track of it.
If you’d like, use a timer to help you keep track of time.
Pour out the solution and rinse off the jewelry.
The water gets rid of any lingering salt, baking soda, or soap, as well as the debris that came off.
Your jewelry is clean when there is no bubbles or residue in the water.
Dry your jewelry with a cloth after it is clean.
Before you put on your jewelry or store it for later use, use a clean towel to pat it dry.
Use either a rag or a paper towel to do this.
